title: Chapter 5: Research Design and Data Analysis

introduction.text: This chapter (Part II of Research Methodology) focuses on Research Design, Sampling, Data collection methods, Data Analysis, Data Interpretation, and Findings. Authored by AASTU, March 2025.

Helps take decisions about how to complete the entire research process:
Step 1: Consider your aims and approach
Step 2: Choose a type of research design
Step 3: Identify your population and sampling method
Step 4: Choose your data collection methods
Step 5: Plan your data collection procedures
Step 6: Decide on your data analysis strategies
Step1: Choose your aims and research approach
Understand subjective experiences, beliefs, and concepts
Gain in-depth knowledge of a specific context or culture
Explore under-researched problems and generate new ideas
and describe frequencies, averages, and correlations
Test the effectiveness of a new treatment, program or product
Qualitative Research Designs: tend to be more flexible and
, allowing you to adjust your approach based on what you find throughout the research process.

for student centered active learning while teaching software engineering courses, a qualitative approach would make the most sense. You can use this type of research to explore exactly what teachers and students struggle with traditional lecture mode class sessions.
Quantitative Research Designs: tend to be more fixed and
clearly defined in advance of data collection.
the effectiveness of an student centered active teaching method, a
approach is most suitable. You can use this type of research to measure learning outcomes like grades and test scores.
Note: Qualitative and quantitative approaches can also be combined to have a complete picture and more credible research result
Step 2: Choose Type of Research Design (Quantitative)
Types of quantitative research designs: Quantitative designs can be split into
Quantitative Design Types: Purpose and Characteristics
Involves manipulating an independent variable and measuring its effect on a dependent variable
Subjects are randomly assigned to groups
Usually conducted in a controlled environment (e.g., a lab)
Similar to experimental design, but without random assignment
Often involves comparing the outcomes of pre-existing groups
Often conducted in a natural environment (higher ecological validity)
Used to test whether (and how strongly) variables are related
Variables are measured without influencing them
Used to describe characteristics, averages, trends, etc
Variables are measured without influencing them

With descriptive and correlational designs, you can get a clear picture of characteristics, trends and relationships as they exist in the real world. However, you can’t draw conclusions about cause and effect (because

You could use a correlational design to find out if the rise in online teaching in the past year correlates with any change in test scores. But this design can’t confirm a causal relationship between the two variables. Any change in test scores could have been influenced by
Experiments are the strongest way to test
relationships without the risk of other variables influencing the results.
always reflect how things work in the real world. They’re
also more difficult and expensive to implement.

In an experimental design, you could gather a sample of students and then randomly assign half of them to be taught with student centered and the other half to be taught in lecture mode, while controlling all other relevant variables. By comparing their outcomes in test scores, you can be more confident that it was the method of teaching (and not other variables) that caused any change in scores.
Qualitative Design Types: Purpose and Characteristics
Detailed study of a specific subject (e.g., a place, event, organization, etc).
Data can be collected using a variety of sources and methods.
Focuses on gaining a holistic understanding of the case.
Detailed study of the culture of a specific community or group.
Data is collected by extended immersion and close observation.
Focuses on describing and interpreting beliefs, conventions, social dynamics, etc.
Aims to develop a theory inductively by systematically analyzing qualitative data.
Aims to understand a phenomenon or event by describing participants' lived experiences.

Step 3: Identify population and Sampling Methods
Your research design should clearly define who or what your research will focus on, and
is the entire group that you want to
is the smaller group of individuals you’ll actually collect data from.
Identifying your population and sampling method

contentBlocks.alt: Diagram showing a large 'Population' group, an arrow 'Select a sample from the population' pointing to a smaller 'Sample' group, and an arrow 'Generalize conclusions from the sample to the population' pointing back to 'Population'.

content.text: Identifying your population: Defining the population
can be made up of anything you want to study—plants, animals, organizations, texts, countries, etc. In the social sciences, it most often refers to a group of people.

We will you focus on people from a specific demographic, region or background? Are you interested in people with a certain job or medical condition, or users of a particular product? The more precisely you define your population, the easier it will be to gather a representative sample.

If you’re studying the effectiveness of student centered teaching in the Ethiopia, it would be very difficult to get a sample that’s representative of all university students in the country. To make the research more manageable, and to draw more precise conclusions, you could focus on a narrower population—for example, 4th year students in urban areas of the country.
Identifying sampling method: Probability vs. Non-probability
Sample is selected using random methods
Allows you to make strong statistical inferences about the population
Sample selected in a non-random way
Used in both qualitative and quantitative research
Easier to achieve, but more risk of

Right side (Non-Probabilistic) shows Systematic, Stratified, Cluster, Voluntary Response, Purposive, Snowball Sampling. Source: www.homeworkjoy.com

caption.text: Types of Sampling Method Techniques and Examples.

content.text: Note: methods in the left side are probabilistic whereas those in the right side are non-probabilistic methods. (Slide image seems to mix Convenience under probabilistic; it's typically non-probabilistic).

According to Uma Sekaran in Research Method for Business 4th Edition, Roscoe (1975) proposed the rules of thumb for determining sample size where sample size larger than 30 and less than 500 are appropriate for most research, and the minimum size of sample should be 30% of the population.

The size of the sample depends on a number of factors and the researchers have to give the statistically information before they can get an answer. For example, these information like (confidence level, standard deviation, margin of error and population size) to determine the sample size.

contentBlocks.alt: Flowchart for hypothesis testing: Data -> State Hypothesis -> Select Test Statistic -> Calculate Test Statistic -> Statistical Decision. If Do not Reject Ho, Conclude Ho may be true. If Reject Ho, Conclude Ha is true.

Diagram showing a normal distribution curve with H0 Accepted region in the middle and Rejection Regions for Null Hypothesis (H0) vs Alternative Hypothesis (H1) on the tails. Source: www.statisticalaid.com
Table showing Type I error (Reject Ho when Ho true) and Type II error (Accept Ho when Ha true), and Correct decisions.

caption.text: Type I and Type II Errors in Hypothesis Testing.

content.text: Levels of Measurement: nominal, ordinal, Interval, ratio
the data can only be categorized
the data can be categorized and ranked
the data can be categorized, ranked, and evenly spaced
the data can be categorized, ranked, evenly spaced, and has a natural zero.

contentBlocks.alt: Visual representation of Nominal (Named variables), Ordinal (Named + ordered variables), Interval (Named + ordered + proportionate interval between variables), and Ratio (Named + ordered + proportionate interval + Can accommodate absolute zero) scales.

content.text: Nominal, ordinal, interval, and ratio data examples
Why are levels of measurement important?
Example: A variable at 2 levels of measurement. You can measure the variable of income at an ordinal or ratio level.

At a ratio level, you can see that the difference between A and B’s incomes is far greater than the difference between B and C’s incomes.
At an ordinal level, however, you only know the income bracket for each participant, not their exact income. Since you cannot say exactly how much each income differs from the others in your data set, you can only order the income levels and group the participants.
Which descriptive statistics can I apply on my data?

Mathematical operations: Equality (=, ≠)
Measures of central tendency: Mode
Measures of variability: None

Mathematical operations: Equality (=, ≠), Comparison (>, <)
Measures of central tendency: Mode, Median
Measures of variability: Range, Interquartile range

Mathematical operations: Equality (=, ≠), Comparison (>, <), Addition, subtraction (+, -)
Measures of central tendency: Mode, Median, Arithmetic mean
Measures of variability: Range, Interquartile range, Standard deviation, Variance

Mathematical operations: Equality (=, ≠), Comparison (>, <), Addition, subtraction (+, -), Multiplication, division (×, ÷)
Measures of central tendency: Mode, Median, Arithmetic mean, *Geometric mean
Measures of variability: Range, Interquartile range, Standard deviation, Variance, **Relative standard deviation
Which statistics can I apply on my data for hypothesis testing?

This slide presents a table showing which statistical tests (Binomial, t-test, Chi-Square, Mann-Whitney U, One-way ANOVA, Kruskal-Wallis, Pearson correlation, Spearman correlation, Point biserial, t-test for paired samples, Wilcoxon-Test, Analysis of variance for repeated measurements, Friedman Test) are applicable for nominal, ordinal, and metric data types.
Is there a difference in the average number of burglaries (dependent variable) in houses with and without alarm systems (independent variable with 2 groups)?
Does the consumption of cigarettes have a negative effect on the blood pressure? (Before and after measurement)
People living in small, medium or large cities (independent variable with three groups) differ in their health awareness (dependent variable).
In qualitative research, your data will usually be very dense with information and ideas. Instead of summing it up in numbers, you’ll need to comb through the data in
Two of the most common approaches:
Characteristics: Focuses on the content of the data. Involves coding and organizing the data to identify key themes.
Characteristics: Focuses on putting the data in context. Involves analyzing different levels of communication (language, structure, tone, etc).
on the aims of your research.

title.text: 2: What type of sampling is used in the following cases?

content.text: i) There are three bags (A, B and C), each with different balls. Bag A has 50 balls, bag B has 100 balls, and bag C has 200 balls. We have to choose a sample of balls from each bag proportionally. Suppose 5 balls from bag A, 10 balls from bag B and 20 balls from bag C.

ii) In researching customer support services in a particular region, we ask your few customers to complete a survey on the products after the purchase. This is a convenient way to collect data. Still, as we only surveyed customers taking the same product. At the same time, the sample is not representative of all the customers in that area.

summary.text: Chapter 5 covered Research Design (plan, structure, strategy), steps in designing research, types of quantitative (experimental, correlational) and qualitative (case study, ethnography) designs, data collection methods (primary/secondary, surveys, interviews, observation), planning procedures (operationalization, reliability, validity, sampling, data management), population and sampling methods, and data analysis strategies (descriptive/inferential statistics, levels of measurement, qualitative analysis).
